jackson had manifested an arbitrary and ungovern
able disposition, in dsregarding orders, laws, and
the constitution, and substituting his own will when
ever he thought by SO dong he could effect favor
Ite object, or promote the service III which he YVES
engaged--a propensity which Mr. Jefferson SAID
was highly Objectionable and dangerous IN an ot-
Ger, however honest and patriotic he might be. In
Short the impression leit on my mind was such,
that it was impossible for me TO conceive under any
circumstances, that MIR. Jefferson could look with
complacency, much less be anxious for the election
| OF General jackson to the Presidency.


! In the month OF May last just as was setting out
from Abenlarle in Virginia, to return to Illinois,
perceived greatly 10 my surprise and regret, that
my name mad been introduced into the electioneer-
ing harangucs and newspaper paragraphs OF the
day and that prejudiced parts"ns were dis
posed 10 call in question the correctness OF the state
ment, said to have been made by me, and to tratuce
my character. Fearing from the temper displayed
that should b. further attacked, and finally driven,
in self defence, to make public statement In rela-
ton to Mr.. Jefersons opinions of General Jackson;
and recollecting a conversation had last WnterwIh
Thomas w. Gmer, gentleman of talents and of
high responsibility of Charlottesville, and learning
that he had repeated the remarks to many 9th
ers. took the liberty to address him note, his
answer 10 which is herewith enclosed. The state
meut of Mr.. Gimer. who was near neighbor OF
Mr. jefferson, you will find, is fully conhrnatory of
mine as to the unfavorabe light in which the Sage
of Monticello viewed General Jackson as states
man. and of my impression that this unfavorable
opinion g was notorious among those who possessed
any share of his contdence; and, if it be not so
much in detail, it more than sustains my statement,
of the total unttness of General Jackson, In the es
limation of Mr.. jefferson, for the Presidency, in the
expression. which Mr. Gilmer says he heard Mr.
Jefferson ssutter with tone of sportiye almost Of
conemptuous derision," that s' might as cell
nuke Sailor of Cock. or Soldier Of Goose, as
a President of .lndrec Jackson"


| am, very respectfully,


EDWARD COLES.


To Messrs. Forquer, Breese, Ford, Prickeu, ~

Copy Of a letter from I. w. Gihner. Esq to Cor
eraor Coles.


CHARACTERISTICS. May 27, 1897


Dear Sir Yours of the 22d was hand d me this
moment. | am tru v mortified at the harsh and m
decornus use which has been made of your name IN
: connection with what to have bee private
conversation The truth is. if II must be tld, that
Mr. Jefferson made no secret OF his opinions OF Gem
ea Jackson. AS soldier and patriot, the Gen.
era was regarded by Mr. Jefferson, as by the Amer
ican People. with admiration and graft ude speak
more from information derived from others, than Of
what know myself when say, that Mr.. Jefvrsons
opinion of General jackson a statesman was less
favorable believe his opinion on this subject was
notorious among those who possessed any share OF
his confidence. | remember to have heard Mr. JET
ferson, on one occasion, an expression, which
struck me. not so much by the sentiment II cantaIn-
ed, (Which, indeed was then very common one IN
Virginia. as the style in which it was made Speak
ing of the several candidates for he Presidency. be-
fore the last election. he remarked that "nne might
as well make sailor of cock. or a soldier OF a
goosp, as President of Andrew Jacksun." These
words made an indeble impression on my memory.
They were uttered with tone of sportise. almost
contemptuous dersiun. MIR. Jefferson was descant-
; ling at the time when this remark was elected. on
the proneness of the Multitude to give man who
possessed one virtue, credit for uhers which he did
not possess. or of tine wants OF discrimination IN the
public mind. where any thing like enthusiasm and
favourtsm was mingled with subject. 1t IS due
perhaps to Justice and truth, to add, that MIR. JEFF
erson, so far as know, entertained opinions equal


y unfayorabIe of the fitness of John Quincy Adams.
as a statesman. think. in the conversation just
alluded to. he spoke of him as having been always
| one thing in politics, and having undergone no acu-
al change since the days ofhis pupage in the school
of the elder Adams.


have detailed as you requested. what remem-
ber Of the conversation of which we spoke last VIM
I ter when together. | have repeatedly heard others
speak of Mr. Jeiferson's sentiments on this subject.
do not recolleet to have heard Mr. Jefferson say
any thing in relation to General Jakson after the late
election. and ii is not for to snrmise what might
have been his opinion at this time, were he alive
must say, in conclusion. that am grleved to find
that the press has stopped so tar below ITS proper
dignity as TO use such unbecomug means to instruct
9 or convince the public. Yours. with very great res
sppct. lHOMAo w. olAMEK.
:. EDWARD Coles. Esq


!, From The National Mteigencer.
: The expressions used by Mr.. Jefferson according
TO Gov. Coles. and corrnborated by Mr.. Gilmer,

After candid pernsal ui the following correspon-
dence, which we find IN the illinois lneigencer Of
the lst inst. not DOUBT Can remain IN the minds OF
our readers as to the character Of the opinion en-
tertaned by Mr. Jefferson, OF the qualifications and
fitness of Gen. jackson for the Presidency. The
letters OF Cove, nur Coles and Gilmer con.
elusive on the point. Mr.. Jefferson treated the
qualifications of Gen. Jackson with unaffected con
tempt; and regarded 1.-THE extraordinary vote he
had received" as ground On which to establish ..a
doubt Of the durability of our Institutions" !"
1t appears from slr. Gimers letter, tina, Mr.
Jefferson was also ininica 10 the claims Of MIR
Adams. participating the Virginia feeling thi.
was o be expected. But his dislike Of MIR. Adams
was excusl. l.eiy political. He had given evidence,
b, the confidence he had himself rep0sed In him.
that he regarded him qualified by intellect and
Wedge for high trusts; anu there is nothing In
the aalner in which he Is described toucnlng the
claims ui Mr.. Adams, which ca parallel the con
temptuuus phrase and feeling winch mark his refer
ence to General Jackson.


We invite our readers every where to read the
facts as detailed in the following letters:


From tte Illinois LatcLigencer


EDwAKDsvILLE, Nov. 20, 1927.
GoUernor Coles:


SIR: We nave seen, in the public journals, opn
ions ,ad TO have been entertained and expressed by
Mr.. Jefferson vi General Jackson, set of which
was SAID to have been communicated to YOU BY that
ustrous man a short time previous to his DEATH
and to the expression of which the Generals extra
ordinary run at the last Presidential election. is sale
to have gwen rise.


The U. 5. Telegraph of the Gath Of October last
asserts, III an editorial article, that you have deni
ed ever making the statements on that subject Whci
have been imputed to YOU, and other papers as con
lenty assert that you have made them. We have
I,nr M aut tla Hncor stpf
by you when this SUBJECT has been jhe topic Of
versatiUn in your presence and have ielt its propr
ETY. but we now think it due to Yourself and thu
people that frank and explicit declaration of tht
facts should BIZ made public. We thereto ask you
to state, with that view, the last conversation you
iad with M. Jefferson in relation to General Jack
snl,, and ms fitness tor the Presdency-the time u
which it was had, and the exact words. as nearly a
you can recoect them. used by llr Jefferson whel
speaking To YOU on that subject


We yenerate the memory u Mr.. Jefferson, ant
profoundly respect his opinions, and wish that thos
he really did entertain and express i'll relation to Gen
Jackson, may l.a gwen to the world


Very respectfully we are, sir, your ob't sery'ts.


George Forquer, Sidney Breese,
| Thomas Fo,d, David Prcket,


Wm 7. 4NKee, Thos. Llpplncott,


Alexander Miller, John Todd.


MADISON COUNTY, ILLINOIS.
/ .Nouember 23, 1897.
| Gentlemen II have seen, with regret, that rc
mark made by Mr. Jefferson to me, in the freedom
OF social and friendly intercourse, and was re
peated in the spritto friend last winter, ,shoul
have found its way into the newspapers. My reluc
taace to appearing before the public, and giving pub
icity to an expression used in conversations has re
strained me from noticing the many unjusfable vel
sons and animadversions which its publication ha
given rise to yielding to the frequent application
made TO me by many ofmy friends and acquaintance
IN make known Mr. Jefferson's opinions of Genera
Jackson's qualifications and fitness for the Preslder
i cv. Nor should now be induced to depart troi
INV purpose of remaining silent, but for the extraol
dnary efforts which have been made, u the peculla
character Of some of the parties concerned, to di
prove the correctness of the opinions OF Mr.. j. q
EXPRESSED to, and repeated by, me. After what ma
past, do not feel myself at liberty any longer
decline making explanations, which have becom
the more necessary FROM the erroneous assertion re
Gently attributed to me, and the improper use mad
of nv name in the public journals: | shall. there


FORE so far yield to the call contained in your lette
of the Goth instant, as to make, in reply to 1t, tn
following statement-under the conviction that
has become net less due to me and to the occasion
than to the opinions of SO respectable IA portion
nv felow-citlzens and with the full persuasonth tn
Iif there be any thing objectionable in my conduc
an excuse will be found in the fact of my name ha
S ing been brought before the public without my COZ
sent, the improper liberties taken with it, and the III
y iustifabe attempts made in disparagement,n mot mer
/ ly of my memory, but OF my character
n On the lth of August, 1925, while on visit
'f Mr. jefferson, at Monticello, had a very long ar
o highly interesting conversation with him, in relate
70 the last Presidential eection in which he spol
: very freely and fully of men and things, and dwe
d at considerable length, on the character, prnclpl
st and conduct, of the gentlemen who had been ca
lie didatcs He expatated dispassonately, and witho


reserve; drew comparisons. made discrimination
and described in his usual forclble language, II


rood and bad traits in the character OF each. /

From the National Journal.
MR.. JEFFEKSON'S OPINION OF GEN. JACK


SON-SEI FLED

by far better qualified that Gen. Jackson to dis
charge the duties of the presidency. In aword, he
spoke of Mr.. Adams an enlightened and exper
fenced statesman of Gen. Jackson valiant and
successful solder-with no other preension to the
Chief Magstracy than that derived from his militia
ry services While conyersng about Gen. jackson,


took occasion to say, that the great zeal which had
been displayed to elect the General, and the extra
ordinary vote he had received, had made me doubt
of the durability of free institutions. Mr. eter
son braced himself in his seat, looked steadlasty at
me, and in the most emphatic manner, said, ''Sr,
IL has caused 10 doubt han any thing aohich
has occurred since The Revoiuion." This part oithe
conversation repeated to Mr.. Williams, and which
regret has fouod its way into the newspapers, and
subjected me to the necessity OF making this COM
munication.


The conversation I held with Mr.. Jefferson, was
not a confidential one. Believing, however, the
language to have been more free and full than he
would have held with every one, | have thought
1t due to that confidence and discretion, which IS
tacty reposed in friends, and usual in the freedom
OF social intercourse not TO speak OF 1t lndlscrl-
minately, much less to give it publicity IN the
newspapers. But | have felt myself at liberty,
using, as conceived, "A proper discretion to re-
peat, both before and since his DEATH many OF his
remarks to particular persons some OF whom
were his neghbors, and others his intimate and con-





posed, he himself would have done, or as would
repeat the free remarks of any other friend made
to me under similar circumstances. And in one
instance, | communicated the substance oil those
he had made in relation to General Jackson IN Il
letter to a mutual friend in Richmond, Va. Though
in some respects, if might be desirable, in conse-
quence of what has past, to give more in detail
the remarks of Mr.. Jefferson there are other and
obvious reasons which induce me to prefer tram
scrlblng the brief statement contained in that let
ter, as it was written by me near two months be-
lore heard OF the death, Or eten illness OF Mr
Jefferson to one who had been in favour of the cleo


ion OF Mr. Crawford, was in opposition to the Fed
eral Administration. and an intimate friend OF Mir.
Jefferson, residing not remote from him and who,
IT he thought had in any respect misconceived Mr.
Jeifers0ns opinions, exposed them in language
too strong, would, presume, have had frequent
personal opportunities OF ascertainlng their accura-
cy from that great man himself In the letter
above alluded to- written from this place, and dat
ed May 80, 1895, are the following remarks
'lf the Crawford men determine to support
Jackson, |, for one cannot go with them. And
am happy to kno1S shall have the company Of
(, Messrs. Jefferson and. The former Mr.. JET
ferson) told me, last Summer, that the zeal which
had been dispayedin favor Of making jackson Pres-
dent, had made him doubt of The duration OF the Re-
public that he did not possess the temper the ac-
qulrements, the assduity, the physical qualifications
for the office and he had been in various civil
offices, and had made figure iii none and that he
had completely failed and shown himself incompe-
tent to i'm Executive trust in Florida; in word,
said the venerable old Patriarch, there are one hun
dred men in Albemarle county better qualified for
the Presidency


These were the opinions expressed by Mr.. JEFF
ferson to me, in August, 1885, and were greatly am
plificdand illustrated by reference to, and state
ments of, the official and personal conduct OF Gene
raj Jackson. Whether Mr. Jefferson afterwards
changed his opinions and thought better OF Ja kson,
or worse of Adams know not for, soon after
holding this conversation with him, returned to
Illinois, and did not again visit Virginia until last
/ Winter. when | must here be permitted to add,
among his numerous friends and acqualntances, with
whom convcrsed, | do not recollect to have met
with single individual who did not seem 10 be per-
fectly aware of the low estimation in which he held
the civil talents and qualifications OF General Jack
i son.--Many of these persons could refer TO- and
repeat expressions they informed me they had heard
i Mr. Jefferson use, did the occasion require 1t, or
Justify nv bringing their names before the public.
feel myself, however, at liberty, from the manner
Fl have received the normation to say that Garret
Minor has letter from his brother, the late Peter
Minor, the neighbor and intimate friend OF Nlr. JET
ferson, detailing opinions expressed by MI. JET
farson, which, informed. very similar to those
he expressed to me. understand Mr.. Minor S con-
yeraation with Mr.. Jefferson to have been subse-
quent to mine.


From my knowledge Of Mr.. jefferson, was con-


vinced he would not be pleased with some parts OF
, the Executive Message of December, 1928 nor
/, with some of the principles avowed, and measures


advocated by the Administration and IFS friends IN
. Congress- | felt persuaded that these things would
render him less satisfied with the present Eyecu-
t tive, and should not have been surprised to have


heard that he was desirous Of seeing the Government
, administered by another But with strong recol-
e lection of the opinions expressed by him. and un-
il der the influence of the deep impression made by
ERzDs4X, December rs, 1927.

CHARACTERISTICS. May 27, 1897

full articles.article:
After candid pernsal ui the following correspon-
dence, which we find IN the illinois lneigencer Of
the lst inst. not DOUBT Can remain IN the minds OF
our readers as to the character Of the opinion en-
tertaned by Mr. Jefferson, OF the qualifications and
fitness of Gen. jackson for the Presidency. The
letters OF Cove, nur Coles and Gilmer con.
elusive on the point. Mr.. Jefferson treated the
qualifications of Gen. Jackson with unaffected con
tempt; and regarded 1.-THE extraordinary vote he
had received" as ground On which to establish ..a
doubt Of the durability of our Institutions" !"
1t appears from slr. Gimers letter, tina, Mr.
Jefferson was also ininica 10 the claims Of MIR
Adams. participating the Virginia feeling thi.
was o be expected. But his dislike Of MIR. Adams
was excusl. l.eiy political. He had given evidence,
b, the confidence he had himself rep0sed In him.
that he regarded him qualified by intellect and
Wedge for high trusts; anu there is nothing In
the aalner in which he Is described toucnlng the
claims ui Mr.. Adams, which ca parallel the con
temptuuus phrase and feeling winch mark his refer
ence to General Jackson.


We invite our readers every where to read the
facts as detailed in the following letters:

by far better qualified that Gen. Jackson to dis
charge the duties of the presidency. In aword, he

took occasion to say, that the great zeal which had
been displayed to elect the General, and the extra
ordinary vote he had received, had made me doubt
of the durability of free institutions. Mr. eter
son braced himself in his seat, looked steadlasty at
me, and in the most emphatic manner, said, ''Sr,
IL has caused 10 doubt han any thing aohich
has occurred since The Revoiuion." This part oithe
conversation repeated to Mr.. Williams, and which

The conversation I held with Mr.. Jefferson, was
not a confidential one. Believing, however, the
language to have been more free and full than he
would have held with every one, | have thought
1t due to that confidence and discretion, which IS
tacty reposed in friends, and usual in the freedom
OF social intercourse not TO speak OF 1t lndlscrl-
minately, much less to give it publicity IN the
newspapers. But | have felt myself at liberty,
using, as conceived, "A proper discretion to re-
peat, both before and since his DEATH many OF his
remarks to particular persons some OF whom
were his neghbors, and others his intimate and con-





posed, he himself would have done, or as would
repeat the free remarks of any other friend made
to me under similar circumstances. And in one
instance, | communicated the substance oil those
he had made in relation to General Jackson IN Il
letter to a mutual friend in Richmond, Va. Though
in some respects, if might be desirable, in conse-
quence of what has past, to give more in detail
the remarks of Mr.. Jefferson there are other and
obvious reasons which induce me to prefer tram
scrlblng the brief statement contained in that let
ter, as it was written by me near two months be-
lore heard OF the death, Or eten illness OF Mr
Jefferson to one who had been in favour of the cleo


ion OF Mr. Crawford, was in opposition to the Fed

'lf the Crawford men determine to support
Jackson, |, for one cannot go with them. And
am happy to kno1S shall have the company Of
(, Messrs. Jefferson and. The former Mr.. JET
ferson) told me, last Summer, that the zeal which

dent, had made him doubt of The duration OF the Re-

for the office and he had been in various civil
offices, and had made figure iii none and that he
had completely failed and shown himself incompe-
tent to i'm Executive trust in Florida; in word,
said the venerable old Patriarch, there are one hun
dred men in Albemarle county better qualified for
the Presidency


These were the opinions expressed by Mr.. JEFF
ferson to me, in August, 1885, and were greatly am
plificdand illustrated by reference to, and state
ments of, the official and personal conduct OF Gene
raj Jackson. Whether Mr. Jefferson afterwards
changed his opinions and thought better OF Ja kson,
or worse of Adams know not for, soon after
holding this conversation with him, returned to
Illinois, and did not again visit Virginia until last
/ Winter. when | must here be permitted to add,
among his numerous friends and acqualntances, with
whom convcrsed, | do not recollect to have met
with single individual who did not seem 10 be per-
fectly aware of the low estimation in which he held
the civil talents and qualifications OF General Jack
i son.--Many of these persons could refer TO- and
repeat expressions they informed me they had heard
i Mr. Jefferson use, did the occasion require 1t, or
Justify nv bringing their names before the public.
feel myself, however, at liberty, from the manner
